column1: [Docs] Enhance docs for extend() based on Community thread
column31:
In the Community thread "[Convert Array to Object|https://community.snaplogic.com/t/convert-array-to-object/1979]," Tim Stack provides information on how to create objects dynamically from other objects using extend(). 

{quote}The extend() method can be used to create objects dynamically from other objects passed in as arguments. In your case, it looks like the objects in the ‘$Array’ field do not have overlapping keys, so you can directly use the array as the arguments to extend. However, you cannot just pass ‘$Array’ to extend(), you need to use the spread operator to indicate that the elements of the array should be treated as the arguments to the function, like so:

{}.extend(...$Array)
The {} part just creates an empty object for us to call extend() on.

There are a few other examples of using the extend() method in the community, like this [one|https://community.snaplogic.com/t/json-array-value-to-column-formating/1950/2?u=tstack].{quote}

It would be good to roll this into https://docs-snaplogic.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SD/pages/1439367/Object+Functions+and+Properties#ObjectFunctionsandProperties-extend

Unable to find any source documentation in the official MySQL Documentation that sheds more light on the concept of batching and connection pooling, a few forums discuss this but in a very generic fashion. I am aware that batching and connection pooling are commonly applied practises in most DBs and I am looking for a much more detailed information about this in terms of maximum and minimum limits, purpose, limitations, best practices, and so on . column195: 27/Nov/17 4:16 PM;aparekh;[~miqbal]: For the purpose of this ticket, all we need is the respective values, since our implementation maybe different. Customers are expected to know what those fields do. [~yzhang]: Can you please provide the min/max values for these properties and any caveats/restrictions, based on our implementation?
column196:
27/Nov/17 5:45 PM;yzhang;[~aparekh] Sure.

*Batch size*
We use JDBC API [java.sql.executeBatch()|https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/sql/Statement.html#executeBatch()] to execute SQL statements in batches, as per the API's description:
bq. Submits a batch of commands to the database for execution and if all commands execute successfully, returns an array of update counts. Batch execution is used to improve the performance.

batch size defines how many SQL statements can be executed in a single batch. For example, when inserting 100 records with batch size as 40, there will be 100 insert statements, and they are executed in 3 batches, the first and second batches contain 40 insert statements each and the third batch contains 20.

It is part of the JDBC standard, there is no maximum limit on the batch size. However, the JDBC drivers don't necessarily follow the standard and could throw exceptions if the batch size is too large for a specific driver, user should reduce the batch size if they see an exception saying the batch size is too large. 

What is a proper batch size depends on the specific db operations. Generally the larger the batch size is, the better the performance would be. But if the batch size is too large, sending a single batch request to the database server can take too long time and it would time out. User should test and monitor the performance with different batch sizes and decide the best batch size.

*Max pool size*
We use HikariCP(https://github.com/brettwooldridge/HikariCP) to do database connection pooling. The max pool size defines the maximum number of concurrent connections in a connection pool.

The number of max pool size depends how many concurrent connections that user needs. Each MySQL Snap holds a separate connection when running. For a pipeline that has 4 MySQL Insert, 2 MySQL Execute and 1 MySQL Update Snaps, the max pool size should be no less than 7 to make sure the pipeline can be executed successfully.

column1: [DOC] update description on Batch size property for Salesforce SOQL/Read Snaps
column31:
The Batch size property description should be replaced with the following phrases in the draft document for 4.12:

Required. This refers to the number of records in each batch during the download of large query results. Each batch read requires an API call against Salesforce to retrieve the set of records.

1. REST API:
The batch size to 200 and 2000 are valid in REST API.
According to the SFDC REST API documentation:
https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.api_rest.meta/api_rest/headers_queryoptions.htm
"There is no guarantee that the requested batch size is the actual batch size. Changes are made as necessary to maximize performance."
In fact, if the size of each record in the query result is relatively large (e.g. a few hundred output fields), SFDC may respond in a batch size of 200, And if the size of each record in the query result is relatively small, SFDC may respond in a batch size of 2000 regardless the Batch size is set to 200 or 2000.

2. Bulk API:
Selecting the values 100,000 or 250,000 will make the Bulk API request as PK-chinking with a chunk size of 100,000 or 250,000.
Other values 200 or 2000 will have the Snap submit a single regular Bulk API batch job to SFDC.
According to the SFDC Bulk API documentation:
https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.api_asynch.meta/api_asynch/asynch_api_concepts_limits.htm
"15 attempts at 10 minutes each to process the batch. There is also a 2-minute limit on the time to process the query. If more than 15 attempts are made for the query, an error message of 'Tried more than fifteen times' is returned. If the query takes more than 2 minutes to process, a QUERY_TIMEOUT error is returned."
Therefore, if the query is expected to take long time to execute (e.g. the target SObject has more than several hundred thousand records and the number of output fields in a record is more than a few hundreds), it is highly recommended to set this property to 100,000 or 250,000 to avoid timeout errors.

15/Feb/18 10:01 AM;efertig;The request was to specifically show supported outbound connections.   I don't see that anything was added for supported outbound connections.   

I believe we've told customers that outbound connections such as a pipeline calling SalesForce, it is entirely dependent on the outside endpoint.    However, outbound connections are not restricted to 1.2.

There is the following article by Oracle:

https://blogs.oracle.com/java-platform-group/entry/java_8_will_use_tls

If negotiation does fail, it could possibly be due to a combination unsupported cyphers or you may possibly need to force negotiation using different JVM switches that can be passed to the 'jcc.jvm_options' directive in the snaplex properties.
e.g., 
-Djdk.tls.client.protocols="TLSv1,TLSv1.1,TLSv1.2"

Behavior will depend on the service endpoint and different services may behave differently.   Because these are global settings for the JCC, we do strongly recommend that any custom settings are isolated specifically to the Snaplexes that would be responsible for communicating to the internal TLS 1.0 endpoint noted.

column1: [Documentation] File Writer should note that colon (:) is not supported in Windows
column31:
This is a request to update our File Writer documentation to note the fact that colons (':') are not supported in Windows filenames. Our snap documentation includes an example, pasted below, for SLDB protocol that works, however, if a customer changes the protocol to something like FTP or FTPS and the destination is Windows, the same expression would fail. 

We should warn users on the page that any protocol that supports a Windows destination will fail if reserved characters like colon (':') are in the filename, or will be inserted into the filename by an expression.

In our File Writer snap documentation we state the following:

                "sldb:///out_" + Date.now() + ".csv"
then the evaluated filename can be:

sldb:///out_2013-11-13T00:22:31.880Z.csv{quote}

https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa365247(v=vs.85).aspx

*Here is a workaround for File Writer snap targeting a Windows-based FTPS server that replaces colons (':') with underscores (_):*

The below description from Ali's email.
_Hello,

When I was onsite at ecoATM last week, someone on their side wanted to be able to modify the HTTP response returned from a triggered task. For example, instead of returning a status 200, return a status 400. 

Both he and I went through the documentation at https://docs-snaplogic.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SD/pages/1438189/How+to+Run+a+Pipeline+from+a+URL+Triggered+Task and noticed the following:
1. The instructions provided do not work (we weren't able to get the status response to change). We tried various different options and approaches based on that help site, but it didn't work. 
2. At times, "status" is mentioned, at other times "http_status_code" is mentioned. So there's an inconsistency. 

We finally were able to get the status code to change, but via a different approach:
I just updated the "Binary Header Properties" in the JSON Formatter snap by having the status code listed there. Screenshot below:
  !JSON_Status code.png|thumbnail! 


Thus, please update the "How to Run a Pipeline from a URL (Triggered Task)" help page by removing the current steps for the status code and replacing with steps indicating to update the JSON Formatter snap. 


Thanks,

Ali
_

column1: [Documentation] [Decompress] Decompress snap has a poorly explained AUTO Scheme
column31:
Current documentation does not include any information on what the AUTO Scheme is for the Decompress snap so people assume it will help automatically select between GZIP/BZIP/Deflate Schemes. 

*Decomress link:* https://docs-snaplogic.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SD/pages/1438748/Decompress

*Screenshot of Settings section:*
 !Apr2018-Decomress_Settings_Screenshot.png|thumbnail! 

*Proposed update to Scheme field:*
{quote}The decompression scheme to use. Use AUTO to ready a plain text file, otherwise select your desired decompression scheme below (AUTO does not automatically select between different schemes). The available options include:{quote}
column193: 24/Apr/18 8:13 AM;tstack;There is an explanation of AUTO in the main Description of the snap and it does auto-detect the format, it is not just for recognizing a plain text file.
column194:
24/Apr/18 8:43 AM;rsramkoski;Thanks for the update [~tstack]. I was basing my understanding off a comment in decompress.java which states, "The user has chosen AUTO and no compression was selected, so we assume the stream is plain text." and observed behavior in the customer's pipeline where AUTO failed to read the file but selecting GZIP always worked. 

I took a deeper look at decompress.java this morning and I see now that we do take a peek at the header of the file for GZIP and BZIP headers. Since that is the case, it seems like the issue would be the file headers, though when I use the 'file' command on it it shows up as GZIP. Perhaps this should instead be an enhancement request to see if we can expand our peek into the headers? I also see that AUTO is described more in the main Description of the snap.
column195: 24/Apr/18 8:45 AM;tstack;Is there are bug for the case where GZIP worked and AUTO did not?
column196: 24/Apr/18 8:47 AM;rsramkoski; Not yet. I can file one and attach the file.
column197: 24/Apr/18 10:06 AM;aparekh;Thanks [~tstack] for clarifying. [~rsramkoski]: Please confirm if we can close this doc story?
column198: 25/Apr/18 1:15 AM;miqbal;Tested this theory, the AUTO scheme decompresses all three compression schemes - GZIP, BZIP2, and DEFLATE. The description mentions that AUTO cannot be used for files compressed using the DEFLATE scheme, I will correct this. To remove any possible ambiguity I will also enhance the description of the SCHEME property.
column199:

column202: 25/Apr/18 8:20 AM;tstack;AUTO *cannot* detect DEFLATE since there is no header.  Please remove that part.

column204:

In this pipeline I have decompressed all supported compression schemes using the AUTO option.
column205: 14/May/18 12:13 PM;tstack;[~miqbal] The compression is detect there because it's in the binary document header.  The Compress snap will add a content-encoding header and the Decompress snap can use that to detect the format (note the content-encoding isn't showing up in the preview because of a platform bug).  But, it is highly unlikely that the binary document fed into the Decompress snap will have that field in the binary header.  So, it would be safer to just say it's not going to work.

column202:
31/Jan/18 10:06 AM;rhowlett;Oh, I'm sorry [~vsrinivasan], I did not pay enough attention to the details of this ticket earlier and I had ticket-blindness when I looked at the "Kafka Consumer Output.png" file above. It was only reading your comment this morning that I finally groked what this customer was experiencing.

I believe this can be solved with a minor modification to the Confluent Kafka Producer Snap's settings. Skip to SOLUTION below if you wish to get to it directly.

Firstly, a summary of what is going wrong. The customer is feeding a document into the Producer Snap. Documents are of course JSON-based. However, the Producer only supports String serialization. What happens under the covers is that the code is basically calling {{.toString()}} on the object used as the message value. For simple values like Strings and numbers (e.g. "ABC" or 123) this will only convert them to a String format.

However, calling {{.toString()}} on a JSON document object can, depending on the underlying implementation, change the actual format of the message entirely. That is what is happening here. So the curly-brace and colon-based format of JSON is converted into a custom, human-readable String representation of that object.

SOLUTION:
To maintain that JSON format, instead of passing for example {{$}} as the Message value, the expression function {{JSON.stringify($)}} will convert the JSON document object to a String, but maintain the JSON format. I would then hope that the Talend consuming application will not have an issue reading and parsing the JSON content.

DEMONSTRATION:

The existing scenario described, resulting in non-JSON being sent:

 !20180131-1100_msg-val-$_invalid-json.png|thumbnail! 

And with the {{JSON.stringify($)}} change with a Mapper demonstrating that JSON content has been sent, consumed and can be parsed:

 !20180131-1105_json-stringify-$_valid-json.png|thumbnail! 

I would communicate the above to the customer ([~vdandu], [~pavan]). And yes, it is not great that we did not see this solution immediately. You can share our apologies.

The Snap reference draft has been updaed:
https://mysnaplogic.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SPD/pages/60571961/Worksheet+Writer

Single batch write:
"If selected, the Snap stores the worksheet data in its internal buffer as it processes the input document stream and writes the entire worksheet data in one batch when it receives the end of input document stream. Google Sheets service limits the total number of cells in a spreadsheet to 2 million cells. A spreadsheet may contain multiple worksheets. The cell count limit applies to the sum of all worksheets in a spreadsheet. If the Snap fetches an input document and it will exceed the cell count limit, the current and all subsequent input documents are written to the error view as part of error documents.

If not selected, the Snap writes the worksheet data one row or one cell at a time. Therefore, when the property is selected, the Snap writes a worksheet much faster than the property not selected. Since the single batch write mode stores the entire worksheet data in its internal buffer, users should make sure the system have sufficient memory.

Default value: Not selected"

column1: [DOC] Update File Poller Snap description
column31:
The Snap description is improved for File Poller:

"This Snap polls a directory looking for files matching the specified pattern. It repeats the polling in every interval given in the Polling interval property until the timeout value given in the Polling timeout property. Directory Browser Snap should be used if more than a few files are to be listed only once. Any subfolder in the directory is ignored.

A typical use case of File Poller Snap is as following:

Initially there is no matching file in a directory and File Poller continue to poll the directory in a given internal. When the Snap finds one or more matching files, it writes one output document for each file. The downstream Snaps processes each document and delete the file at the end of the processing before the time value of the Polling interval property lapses. If the matched files are not deleted within the polling interval, the same path will be written to the output view of the File Poller Snap. It completes the execution when it reaches the time value of the Polling timeout property."

column1: [Docs] Set custom character set to SQL Server Bulk Load Snap
column31:
SQL server bulk load snap invokes bcp utlity internally to load the bulk data into SQL server tables. 

Snaplogic snaps are defined to work at UTF-8 default character set. But when bcp (SS bulk load) snap writes data to target tables, some of the special and multi byte characters are written as junk characters. This behavior is because our Snaplex uses character sets defined on OS which they are installed (Windows in this case)

In order to set the desired character set, following batch file needs to be edited.

Make a bcp.bat batch file with these contents:

bcp.exe %* -C 1252

and then set the bcp.bat file as the absolute path to bcp and it will correctly set the codepage for BCP. 

Please have this feature tested and add to documentation.

Please Note - This is only applicable for *Windows based Snaplexes.*

column1: [Doc] add description for new property 'Validate input data'
column31:
Added a description for 'Validate input data' property into Confluence draft document for Redshift Bulk Load Snap:

"If selected, the Snap checks if all input documents are flat map data. Flat map data is a collection of key/value pairs, where the values are all single class objects other than Map or List. If any value is a Map or a List object, the Snap writes an error to the error view. If this condition happens, no document is written to the output view. If input documents are not flat map data, users may use Mapper Snap to transform the value to a data type which corresponds to the column data type in the target Redshift table. If this property is not selected, the Snap does not check input documents, converts all values to strings, writes S3 CSV file, and executes Redshift COPY command. If COPY command finds error in the input CSV data, errors are written to the error table and the Snap routes these errors to the error view. However, some errors reported by COPY command may not be easy to understand. Therefore, it is recommended to select this property during the pipeline building and testing, which may help troubleshoot the pipeline."
